messages.message:
Towards the end of their 34-day war in 2006, the Israeli Army sent tanks into southern Lebanon.
Advertisement"Out of the 400 tanks involved in the fighting in southern Lebanon, 48 were hit, 40 were damaged, and 20 penetrated.
Israeli tanks suffered losses to Hezbollah during their 2006 war in Lebanon.
Any cross-border incursion by Israeli armor would undoubtedly have cover and protection from accompanying infantry, artillery, aircraft, and drones.
"The idea is that the first missile is taken out by an Israeli tank's Trophy defense system, but (that active protection system) doesn't have time to counter the second missile.

Lebanon is 'not tank country' and an Israeli armored assault there exposes it to Hezbollah's firepowerHezbollah took a heavy toll on Israeli armor the last time they fought on the ground in Lebanon.
Towards the end of their 34-day war in 2006, the Israeli Army sent tanks into southern Lebanon.
"Out of the 400 tanks involved in the fighting in southern Lebanon, 48 were hit, 40 were damaged, and 20 penetrated.
Any cross-border incursion by Israeli armor would undoubtedly have cover and protection from accompanying infantry, artillery, aircraft, and drones.
"The idea is that the first missile is taken out by an Israeli tank's Trophy defense system, but (that active protection system) doesn't have time to counter the second missile.

"For us, the most basic of essentials in our lives are not available," a woman, Ibtihal Al-Breim, told Reuters in Khan Younis.
The Israeli military said dozens of militants had been killed in Khan Younis by its tanks and warplanes or in close-quarter combat.
Residents in Khan Younis said tanks remained stationed deep inside Bani Suhaila, east of downtown Khan Younis.
CEASEFIRE HOPESIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is in Washington this week, told families of hostages held in Gaza that a deal that would secure their release could be near.
(Reporting by Nidal al-Mughrabi in Cairo, Maayan Lubell in Jerusalem and Husam Al-Masri in Khan Younis, Gaza StripAdditional reporting by Ahmed Mohamed Hassan in CairoEditing by Angus MacSwan, Gareth Jones, Peter Graff)

Israel tanks advance deeper in southern Gaza as more ceasefire talks expected5 minutesBy Nidal al-Mughrabi, Maayan Lubell and Hussam Al-MasriCAIRO/JERUSALEM/GAZA (Reuters) -Palestinian residents of eastern neighbourhoods of Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip fled their homes on Tuesday as Israeli tanks advanced deep into the area after Israel ordered the population to evacuate.
“For us, the most basic of essentials in our lives are not available,” a woman, Ibtihal Al-Breim, told Reuters in Khan Younis.
The Israeli military said dozens of militants had been killed in Khan Younis by its tanks and warplanes or in close-quarter combat.
Residents in Khan Younis said tanks remained stationed deep inside Bani Suhaila, east of downtown Khan Younis.
(Reporting by Nidal al-Mughrabi in Cairo, Maayan Lubell in Jerusalem and Husam Al-Masri in Khan Younis, Gaza StripAdditional reporting by Ahmed Mohamed Hassan in CairoEditing by Angus MacSwan, Gareth Jones, Peter Graff)

Israel tanks advance deeper in southern Gaza as more ceasefire talks expectedWorld World Israel tanks advance deeper in southern Gaza as more ceasefire talks expectedHealth officials said Israeli military strikes since Monday killed at least 80 people in Khan YounisFollow on Published On: Wed, 24 Jul 2024 09:04:42 PKTCAIRO/JERUSALEM/GAZA (Reuters) – Palestinian residents of eastern neighbourhoods of Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip fled their homes on Tuesday as Israeli tanks advanced deep into the area after Israel ordered the population to evacuate.
"For us, the most basic of essentials in our lives are not available," a woman, Ibtihal Al-Breim, told Reuters in Khan Younis.
The Israeli military said dozens of militants had been killed in Khan Younis by its tanks and warplanes or in close-quarter combat.
Residents in Khan Younis said tanks remained stationed deep inside Bani Suhaila, east of downtown Khan Younis.
CEASEFIRE HOPESIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is in Washington this week, told families of hostages held in Gaza that a deal that would secure their release could be near.

CAIRO/JERUSALEM/GAZA — Palestinian residents of eastern neighbourhoods of Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip fled their homes on Tuesday (July 23) as Israeli tanks advanced deep into the area after Israel ordered the population to evacuate.
"For us, the most basic of essentials in our lives are not available," a woman, Ibtihal Al-Breim, told Reuters in Khan Younis.
The Israeli military said dozens of militants had been killed in Khan Younis by its tanks and warplanes or in close-quarter combat.
Residents in Khan Younis said tanks remained stationed deep inside Bani Suhaila, east of downtown Khan Younis.
Ceasefire hopesIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is in Washington this week, told families of hostages held in Gaza that a deal that would secure their release could be near.

Earlier this month, Marvel Comics shared a teaser for its next wave of Star Wars storytelling.
We've now learned that this exploration of the post-Return of the Jedi era will begin in Star Wars: Battle of Jakku - Insurgency Rising.
STAR WARS: BATTLE OF JAKKU — INSURGENCY RISING #1Written by ALEX SEGURAArt by LEONARD KIRK & STEFANO RAFFAELEA Defiant Imperial takes center stage — and goes on the offensive against the New Republic!
STAR WARS: BATTLE OF JAKKU — INSURGENCY RISING #3Written by ALEX SEGURAArt by JETHRO MORALES & LEONARD KIRKWho is the mysterious Reyna Oskur — and what does her influence over the Defiant Imperial mean for the New Republic?
STAR WARS: BATTLE OF JAKKU — INSURGENCY RISING #4Written by ALEX SEGURAArt by JETHRO MORALES & LEONARD KIRK

STAR WARS: BATTLE OF JAKKU — INSURGENCY RISING #2Written by ALEX SEGURAArt by LEONARD KIRKTHE NEW REPUBLIC FACES DEADLY ADVERSARIES!
Mon Mothma and Leia must make a difficult decision to deal with a defiant Imperial hell-bent on preserving the legacy of Palpatine and Vader!
STAR WARS: BATTLE OF JAKKU — INSURGENCY RISING #3Written by ALEX SEGURAArt by JETHRO MORALES & LEONARD KIRKKES DAMERON FACES DEATH IN THE GRIP OF A FEARSOME IMPERIAL THREAT!
Who is the mysterious Reyna Oskur — and what does her influence over the Defiant Imperial mean for the New Republic?
STAR WARS: BATTLE OF JAKKU — INSURGENCY RISING #4Written by ALEX SEGURAArt by JETHRO MORALES & LEONARD KIRKCHAOS REIGNS AS THE DEFIANT IMPERIAL COMES FACE-TO-FACE WITH THE HEROES OF THE NEW REPUBLIC!

fdfe7380-53ce-468a-a12e-927b39981aaa.location: The Battle of Jakku - Insurgency Rising takes place on the planet Jakku

messages.message:
The Islamic State group declared a self-styled caliphate in a large swath of territory in Syria and Iraq that it seized in 2014.
Islamic State militants pass a checkpoint bearing the group’s trademark black flag in 2014 (Hadi Mizban/AP)Mr Pedersen warned the Security Council of Syria’s delicate security situation.
“The threat of regional conflict cascading over Syria has not abated, particularly with an uptick in Israeli strikes on Syria,” Mr Pedersen said.
Mr Rajasingham and Mr Pedersen called for increased humanitarian access to Syria and international funding.
Mr Wood said the US “will not normalise relations with the Syrian regime or lift sanctions absent an authentic and enduring political solution”.

UNITED NATIONS — The top U.N. envoy for Syria told the Security Council on Monday that the threat of terrorism is ''resurging'' with attacks by Islamic State extremists set to double this year, endangering civilians already facing a ''protracted state of displacement and dire humanitarian conditions.''
The Islamic State group declared a self-styled caliphate in a large swath of territory in Syria and Iraq that it seized in 2014.
Pedersen warned the Security Council of Syria's delicate security situation.
''The threat of regional conflict cascading over Syria has not abated, particularly with an uptick in Israeli strikes on Syria,'' Pedersen said.
Iranian Ambassador Amir Saeed Iravani said the attacks ''flagrantly violate international humanitarian law'' and are a ''serious threat to regional peace and security.''

The top UN envoy for Syria told the Security Council on Monday that the threat of terrorism is “resurging” with attacks by Islamic State extremists set to double this year, endangering civilians already facing a “protracted state of displacement and dire humanitarian conditions”.
The Islamic State group declared a self-styled caliphate in a large swath of territory in Syria and Iraq that it seized in 2014.
“The threat of regional conflict cascading over Syria has not abated, particularly with an uptick in Israeli strikes on Syria,” Mr Pedersen said.
Mr Rajasingham and Mr Pedersen called for increased humanitarian access to Syria and international funding.
Mr Wood said the US “will not normalise relations with the Syrian regime or lift sanctions absent an authentic and enduring political solution”.

Four teens have been jailed for murdering a defenceless 16-year-old boy in a frenzied Melbourne street attack.
She handed down their sentences on Wednesday morning, describing the attack as a frantic two minutes of "incalculable inhumanity".
Three other members of the group were jailed a week earlier for their roles in the killing.
A 16-year-old boy, who was 14 at the time of the attack, was jailed for up to 15 years after pleading guilty to murder.
Two 18-year-olds, who were 16 when charged, were handed youth detention sentences of three and a-half and four years.

Four teens have been jailed for murdering a defenceless 16-year-old boy in a frenzied and brutal Melbourne street attack.
Declan Cutler was walking alone down a dark street when he was stabbed by a group of eight boys.
Declan Cutler was stabbed to death after a party in Melbourne.
(Nine)Three other members of the group were jailed a week earlier for their roles in the killing.
A 16-year-old boy, who was 14 at the time of the attack, was jailed for up to 15 years after pleading guilty to murder.

Police arrested a 24-year-old man on suspicion of attempted murder after the serviceman was attacked near Brompton Barracks in Gillingham.
The victim, in his 40s, suffered "serious injuries" in the attack, before being airlifted to hospital for treatment.
The Army has declined to comment on reports that the soldier was in uniform at the time.
Writing on X, formerly Twitter, John Healey said: "Shocking to hear of an attack on a soldier in Kent.
Officers attended the scene and at approximately 6.20pm a 24-year-old local man was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder.

The victim, in his 40s, suffered “serious injuries” in the attack in Kent, an Army spokesman said.
The Army declined to comment on reports that the soldier was in uniform at the time.
One man has been arrested on suspicion of attempted murder.
An Army spokesman said: “We’re very sorry to confirm that a soldier has sustained serious injuries in an attack in Chatham, Kent.
“Officers attended the scene and at approximately 6.20pm a 24-year-old local man was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder.

It is the first time the South Korean leader's office, which is a designated no-fly zone, has been hit by balloons launched by Pyongyang.
The latest incident comes days after South Korea's military reacted to the escalating launches by restarting propaganda broadcasts from loudspeakers along the border.
North and South Korea have both used balloons in their propaganda campaigns since the Korean War in the 1950s.
The launches have escalated this year, with thousands of balloons being sent by the North across the border since May.
Wednesday's balloons marked the North's tenth launch this year, in what it claims is retaliation for balloons sent by South Korean activists.

Trash balloons land near S Korea president's officeGetty Images File photo of one of many trash balloons that have landed in South Korea over the past few weeksBalloons carrying rubbish sent by North Korea have landed in South Korea's presidential compound in the capital city of Seoul, say officials.
It is the first time the South Korean leader's office, which is a designated no-fly zone, has been hit by balloons launched by Pyongyang.
The latest incident comes days after South Korea's military reacted to the escalating launches by restarting propaganda broadcasts from loudspeakers along the border.
EPA-EFE/REX/Shutterstock Balloons spotted floating above the South Korean presidential compound in Seoul on WednesdayNorth and South Korea have both used balloons in their propaganda campaigns since the Korean War in the 1950s.
Wednesday's balloons marked the North's tenth launch this year, in what it claims is retaliation for balloons sent by South Korean activists.

The man accused of stabbing writer Sir Salman Rushdie in 2022 in New York now faces a new charge of supporting a terrorist group.
Hadi Matar has been charged with providing material support to the Lebanon-based militant group Hezbollah, according to an indictment unsealed on Wednesday.
He is also charged with attempted murder and assault for the 2022 attack which left Mr Rushdie blind in one eye.
The indictment said Mr Matar attempted to provide "material support and resources" to Hezbollah, knowing it was a terrorist organization, but the document did not detail what evidence connected him to the group.
In an interview with the BBC earlier this year, Sir Salman recalled Mr Matar "sprinting up the stairs" and stabbing him 12 times.

Rushdie attacker charged with supporting militant group HezbollahHe is also charged with attempted murder and assault for the 2022 attack which left Mr Rushdie blind in one eye.
The federal charges come weeks after Mr Matar rejected an offer from prosecutors that would have sentenced him to prison for a shorter period of time if he pleaded guilty.
Hadi Matar has been charged with providing material support to the Lebanon-based militant group Hezbollah, according to an indictment unsealed on Wednesday.
The man accused of stabbing writer Sir Salman Rushdie in 2022 in New York now faces a new charge of supporting a terrorist group.
In an interview with the BBC earlier this year, Sir Salman recalled Mr Matar "sprinting up the stairs" and stabbing him 12 times.

Buffalo (US), Jul 24 (AP) A man who severely injured author Salman Rushdie in a frenzied knife attack in western New York faces a new charge that he supported a terrorist group.
Rushdie detailed the attack and his long and painful recovery in a memoir published in April.
The attack raised questions about whether Rushdie had gotten proper security protection, given that he is still the subject of death threats.
An Italian translator survived a knife attack the same year.
The investigation into Rushdie's stabbing focused partly on whether Matar had been acting alone or in concert with militant or religious groups.

Matar, who severely injured author Salman Rushdie in a frenzied knife attack in western New York faces a new charge that he supported a terrorist group.
An indictment unsealed in U.S. District Court in Buffalo on Wednesday, July 24, 2024, charges Matar with providing material support to Hezbollah, a militant group based in Lebanon and backed by Iran.
Recommended VideosHadi Matar, a U.S. citizen from New Jersey, was attempting to carry out a fatwa, Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles Kruly said.
The author spent years in hiding after the Ayatollah Khomeini of Iran issued a fatwa in 1989 calling for Rushdie's death over his novel “The Satanic Verses.” Khomeini considered the book blasphemous.
An Italian translator survived a knife attack the same year.

A man who severely injured author Salman Rushdie in a frenzied knife attack in western New York faces a new charge that he supported a terrorist group.
Defense attorney Nathaniel Barone, left, and Hadi Matar, 24, right, listen during an arraignment in the Chautauqua County Courthouse in Mayville, NY., Thursday, Aug. 18, 2022.
Rushdie told "60 Minutes" that writing the memoir was the only way he could grapple with what had happened.
The attack raised questions about whether Rushdie had gotten proper security protection, given that he is still the subject of death threats.
An Italian translator survived a knife attack the same year.

The body of Abd-Nasser Sarhan, the officer in the security apparatus of the Palestinian Authority who was killed by IDF fire tonight, with a ribbon of the Al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades of Fatah on his head.

As mentioned, Fatah announced a strike today in Tubas following his death.

Fatah-identified channels claim: Abd-Nasser Sarhan, an officer in the security apparatus of the Palestinian Authority in Tubas was killed tonight after he exposed special forces of the IDF and exchanged fire with them.

The Fatah movement announced a general strike today in Tubas to mourn his death (Sarhan himself is a resident of the Balata refugee camp in Nablus but was killed in Tubas).
